title: Proper Unitary Divisors
content: **properUnitaryDivisors**: The set of proper unitary divisors of n: {d | 1 ≤ d < n, d | n, gcd(d, n/d) = 1}. 'Unitary' means d and its complement n/d share no common prime factors.

title: Unitary Perfect Number
content: **IsUnitaryPerfect**: n is a unitary perfect number if the sum of its proper unitary divisors equals n and n > 0. Analogous to ordinary perfect numbers but using unitary divisors.

title: One is Unitary Divisor
content: **one_mem_properUnitaryDivisors**: For n > 1, we have 1 ∈ properUnitaryDivisors n. Proof: 1 | n and gcd(1, n) = 1 always holds.

title: Odd Unitary Divisors
content: **odd_of_unitaryDivisor_of_odd**: If n is odd and d is a unitary divisor of n, then d is odd. Proof: If d were even, 2 | d, hence 2 | n (since d | n), contradicting n odd.

title: Sum Parity Lemma
content: **sum_odd_parity** (axiom): Sum of odd numbers is odd iff the count is odd. This is the key parity lemma: ∑(odd numbers) ≡ count (mod 2).

title: Unitary Perfect Numbers are Even
content: **even_of_isUnitaryPerfect** (axiom): All unitary perfect numbers are even. The proof uses the divisor pairing d ↔ n/d and parity constraints to derive a contradiction for odd n.

title: 6 is Unitary Perfect
content: **isUnitaryPerfect_6** (axiom): 6 = 2·3 is unitary perfect. Proper unitary divisors: 1 (gcd(1,6)=1), 2 (gcd(2,3)=1), 3 (gcd(3,2)=1). Sum: 1+2+3=6.

title: 60 is Unitary Perfect
content: **isUnitaryPerfect_60** (axiom): 60 = 2²·3·5 is unitary perfect. Proper unitary divisors: 1, 3, 4, 5, 12, 15, 20. Sum: 1+3+4+5+12+15+20=60.

title: 90 is Unitary Perfect
content: **isUnitaryPerfect_90** (axiom): 90 = 2·3²·5 is unitary perfect. Proper unitary divisors: 1, 2, 5, 9, 10, 18, 45. Sum: 1+2+5+9+10+18+45=90.

title: The Open Conjecture
content: **erdos_1052_conjecture** (OPEN): The set of unitary perfect numbers is finite. Only 5 are known despite extensive computational searches.

title: Unitary Characterization
content: **unitary_iff_no_common_prime**: gcd(d, n/d) = 1 iff no prime divides both d and n/d. This is the prime-factorization characterization of unitary divisors.

title: Unitary Divisor Sum
content: **unitaryDivisorSum**: σ*(n) = sum of all unitary divisors of n (including n itself). For unitary perfect n: σ*(n) = 2n.

title: Prime Power Divisors
content: **unitaryDivisors_primePow** (axiom): For prime power p^k, the only unitary divisors are 1 and p^k. If d = p^j with 0 < j < k, then gcd(p^j, p^(k-j)) = p > 1.

title: Multiplicativity
content: **unitaryDivisorSum_mul_coprime** (axiom): σ*(mn) = σ*(m)·σ*(n) for coprime m, n. This multiplicativity follows from the bijection between unitary divisors of mn and pairs of unitary divisors of m and n.

title: Unitary Complement
content: **unitary_complement**: If d is a unitary divisor of n (gcd(d, n/d) = 1), then n/d is also unitary since gcd(n/d, d) = gcd(d, n/d) = 1 by commutativity. This creates the pairing d ↔ n/d.
